alert.note: Alert for Box Elder; Cache; Davis; Morgan; Salt Lake; Tooele; Weber (Utah) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Snow Squall Warning issued January 09 at 5:41PM MST until January 09 at 6:15PM MST by NWS Saltlake
info.description: The National Weather Service in Salt Lake City has issued a * Snow Squall Warning for... Weber County in northern Utah... Southwestern Cache County in northern Utah... Southeastern Box Elder County in northern Utah... Northwestern Salt Lake County in northern Utah... Davis County in northern Utah... West central Morgan County in northern Utah... Northeastern Tooele County in northern Utah... * Until 615 PM MST. * At 540 PM MST, a dangerous snow squall was located along a line extending from 12 miles southeast of Hyrum to 11 miles northeast of Delle, moving southeast at 50 mph. HAZARD...Flash freeze on roads. Intense bursts of heavy snow. Gusty winds leading to blowing snow and visibility rapidly falling to less than one-quarter mile. Wind gusts greater than 50 mph could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. SOURCE...Department of transportation officials, doppler radar and webcams. This squall has a history of producing visibility near zero, wind gusts to 70 mph and flash freeze conditions. IMPACT...Dangerous and life-threatening travel conditions are expected to develop rapidly in the warning area. This includes the following highways... Interstate 15 between mile markers 321 and 364. Interstate 84 between mile markers 82 and 106. Interstate 80 in Utah between mile markers 83 and 87. Locations impacted include... Ogden, Layton, Farmington, Brigham City, Morgan, Hill Air Force Base, Roy, Clearfield, Kaysville, Syracuse, Clinton, North Ogden, South Ogden, Centerville, Washington Terrace, Riverdale, Hooper, South Weber, Perry, and Willard. PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Wet roadways will quickly freeze. Black ice will cause roads, bridges, and overpasses to become slick and dangerous. Slow down and be prepared for a sudden loss of traction. Consider avoiding or delaying travel until the snow squall passes your location. If you must travel, use extra caution and allow extra time. Rapid changes in visibility and slick road conditions may lead to accidents. SNOW SQUALL...OBSERVED SNOW SQUALL IMPACT...SIGNIFICANT
